did.unittitle: Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service records

physdesc.extent: in three record cartons, three and a half manuscript boxes, and five oversize boxes. Plus BCCS records of 23 manuscript boxes, 3 scrapbooks, and photos (how much)?

did.abstract: The Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service records measure 30 linear feet and date from circa 1860 to 1990. In addition to the records of the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service, the collection also contains records of four predecessor organizations, namely the Brooklyn Children's Aid Society, Sheltering Arms Nursery, Brooklyn Bureau of Charities, and Brooklyn Bureau of Social Service. Material in the collection include annual reports, publications, nursery and orphanage registers, minutes, correspondence, photographs, slides, and film.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service records consist of the records of four related aid organizations including: Brooklyn Children's Aid Society, Sheltering Arms Nursery, Brooklyn Bureau of Charities, and Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service (now Brooklyn Community Services). The collection is organized into four series: Brooklyn Children's Aid Society, Sheltering Arms Nursery, Brooklyn Bureau of Charities, and Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service.

did.unittitle: Series 1: Brooklyn Children's Aid Society records

physdesc.extent: in two manuscript boxes and three oversize boxes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes Brooklyn Children's Aid Society (BCAS) annual reports, 1870-1946, two publications titled Summer Relief for Little Children and Thirty-Five Years of Saving Services, and three Children's Day registers, 1937-1947.

The first register documents children admitted to BCAS, 1939-1944, while the second register continues from 1945 to 1946. The third register appears to document children admitted for the years 1937-1947. All three registers list the name of child admitted; case, city, and state numbers; dates the children were admitted, committed, expiration, and discharged; who the children were committed by (public agency or relatives); date of birth of the child and age of the child when committed; if the children were committed or non-committed to boarding homes, Herriman, or Wavecrest; remarks; and temporary home.

physdesc.extent: in one oversize box and one folder.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Sheltering Arms Nursery (SAN) records include annual reports and two oversize registers. The registers log information about each child admitted to SAN and include the following categories: age of child, religious affiliation, health status upon arrival, family information such as the reason the child was admitted, ethnic heritage, and the date and reason the child was discharged from SAN.

did.unittitle: Series 3: Brooklyn Bureau of Charities records

physdesc.extent: in three record cartons, one and a half manuscript boxes, and one oversize box.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains the Bureau's annual reports and records of three divisions of the Bureau: Visiting Nurse Association of Brooklyn, Department of Blind and Crippled Children, and the Courts Committee.

did.unittitle: Series 4: Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service records and photographs

physdesc.extent: in 23 manuscript boxes, three oversize scrapbooks, and one record carton.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is further arranged into two subseries: Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service records and Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service photographs.

did.unittitle: Subseries 1: Brooklyn Bureau of Community Services records

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of records relating to the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Services, its predecessor organizations, and to the history of Brooklyn. Items include minutes, reports, correspondence, serials, monographs, scrapbooks, and a banner "Brooklyn Day for the Blind and Handicapped."

did.unittitle: Subseries 2: Brooklyn Bureau of Community Services photographs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains photographs, albums, glass and film slides, and 35mm and 16mm film. Though many of the photographs were composed shots, the lantern slides show the realities of life in poverty/tenements? Most of the material shows the work of the organization helping individuals with physical disabilities. It also includes images of staff events, such as dinners. The film and glass slides document the poor in a manner similar to Jacob Riis. The film footage mostly shows the blind “learning to deal with the environment." Information in the collection folder also provides some description of particular object numbers and their subjects, such as "work w/blind" and "camp outdoors"

Album V1991.110.303 seems to have Brooklyn Week for the Blind as its theme; all the images with this album # were probably taken on or before May of 1950. V1991.110.304 consists of photos removed from between the leaves of a scrapbook, pertaining to the Brooklyn Week for the Blind in 1957, 1958, and 1959. The scrapbook is now under 1991.002 Box 21. V1991.110.301 consists of photos from the 1970s dealing with job training for mentally disabled children at St. Finbar's School. The album is in need of conservation, to remove photos stuck to deteriorating and yellowed adhesive.
